history.content:
IEOR 171 (not 172, 190 series, 191) does count towards the 45 engineering units.

The required courses which count towards the 45 engineering units are EE 20, EE 40, and the 61 series (not CS 70). The remainder of the classes will be from your 20 upper-division EECS courses and then a minimum of 5 units from additional upper-division EECS or engineering courses. Math, Stats, Physics, Bio, and Chem all fall under the Math and Natural Science categories not engineering units. You also cannot use DeCal and self-paced CS 9 courses towards the 45 engineering units.

IEOR 171 (not 172, 190 series) does count towards the 45 engineering units.

The required courses which count towards the 45 engineering units are EE 20, EE 40, and the 61 series. The remainder of the classes will be from your 20 upper-division EECS courses and then a minimum of 5 units from additional upper-division EECS or engineering courses. Math, Stats, Physics, Bio, and Chem all fall under the Math and Natural Science categories not engineering units. You also cannot use DeCal and self-paced CS 9 courses towards the 45 engineering units.

IEOR 171 (not 172, 190 series) does count towards the 45 engineering units.

The required courses which count towards the 45 engineering units are EE 20, EE 40, 61 series, and CS 70. The remainder of the classes will be from your 20 upper-division EECS courses and then a minimum of 5 units from additional upper-division EECS or engineering courses. Math, Stats, Physics, Bio, and Chem all fall under the Math and Natural Science categories not engineering units. You also cannot use DeCal and self-paced CS 9 courses towards the 45 engineering units.

children.subject: No, there are not so you will need to take another 3-4 unit course.  Some students recommend taking Engineering 120 (3 units) as part of your 45 engineering units.
Does that mean classes like E 93 or E 92 which are 1 unit engineering seminars will not count towards the 45 units?
Are there any 1 unit engineering courses for the 45 unit requirements? I only need 1 more unit
Hi- do you mean toward the L&S CS technical electives? If so, the answer is yes, and here is the list: http://www.eecs.berkeley.edu/csugrad/tech_electives
But... At the bottom it says "Except IEOR 171"
You're totally right- it says IEOR 171 does NOT satisfy L&S CS tech electives.
Does IEOR 171 count towards CS ELECTIVE?

The ethics requirement would not count since they are considered Humanities/Social Sciences and not technical courses since you can take them pass/no pass. The design course would count as one of your upper-division EECS courses (and therefore count towards the 20 unit EECS upper-division unit minimum which is part of the 45 engineering unit requirement).
Does the ethics or design requirement count towards the 45 units?

CS 70 does not count towards the 45 engineering units you need to graduate.  CS 70 falls under the Math category for EECS (see EECS Degree Worksheet: http://engineering.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/docs/eecs-worksheet-2014.pdf).  Since it falls under the Math requirement for EECS, the quote you have above doesn't apply since it is already a part of your degree requirements.  As you can see from the PDF worksheet I have included, only the CS 61 series and EE 20 and EE 40 count towards the 45 engineering units.  If this is unclear still, you can schedule an appointment to meet with me since you are my student and we can further discuss this.

CS 10, E120, and E177 would all count towards your 45 engineering units.

Are you sure CS70 is not included in the engineering units? because it is not excluded in the EECS engineering guide:

http://engineering.berkeley.edu/academics/undergraduate-guide/academic-departments-programs/electrical-engineering-computer-sciences

"Students must complete a minimum of 45 units of Engineering coursework. The 45 units of engineering courses cannot include: any course taken on a P/NP basis; courses numbered 24, 39, 84; BioE 100; CS C79, 195, H195; Engin 125, 130AC, 140, 157AC; IEOR 172, 185, 186, 190 series, 191, 192; ME 191AC, 190K, 191K."

Also, does CS10 count to the EECS engineering units?

Thank you.

That's not why CS10 exists. 😢

For the most part CS10 tries to auto-drop students once you have taken 61A.

If you somehow manage to sneak by then maybe, but it's likely not going to work.

Does when you take CS 10 affect whether it counts towards the 45 engineering units? For example, if I took CS 10 after I took the 61-series/upper-division CS courses, would I still get 4 units for CS 10 for my 45 engineering units?

CS 70 Count for Engineering Units

On the degree worksheet, CS 70 is not listed as an 'Engineering' Course. Does it count towards the 45 Engineering units that we are required to take?

history.content:
1. Does IEOR 171 count for the required EECS 45 technical units?

2. What departments/classes count for the EECS 45 technical units? Only Engineering departments, Math, Bio, Chem, and Physics?
history.subject: 45 technical units
